7.83.text:
My name is Jennifer, I work in Meaningful
Innovation at Rickshaw Travel and when I visited

15.72.text: Some of you are thinking, so what?

22.37.text:
Or maybe you’re thinking wow! That sounds
cool!

24.75.text:
Or you might be completely… appalled…
Why? Why would you be appalled?

32.10.text:
Well, it’s gaining traction now in the media
that elephants used for riding, particularly

39.67.text:
in Asia, have often undergone unspeakable
cruelty to get them to obey humans.

47.30.text:
Elephants are herd animals and have never
been domesticated in the way that dogs or

52.01.text:
cats or horses have been, so in order to ‘train’
an elephant, babies are taken from their mothers

59.07.text:
and their spirit is broken through isolation,
starvation and beating. This is an animal

66.53.text:
that is now ranked alongside chimps and dolphins
in terms of intelligence.

71.34.text:
And as tourists we’re not just encouraging
this, we’re fuelling it. Riding elephants

78.42.text:
is not part of Thai culture it has developed
specifically in response to tourist demand

84.29.text:
and is causing a predicted 100 elephants a
year to be poached specifically for tourism.

91.80.text:
So, why did I do it?
Because I didn’t know. I had no idea and

100.96.text:
I loved elephants and I wanted to get close
to them, which, undeniably, I did. I did get

106.48.text:
close to them.
What is Meaningful Travel?

108.61.text:
But was it Meaningful?
What do I mean by that? Was it Meaningful?

115.84.text:
I’m talking about experiences where everybody
benefits, where everybody gets something out

121.07.text:
of it.
Where you or I, as a traveller, get a unique

124.82.text:
insight into a different culture, come face
to face with people who have a completely

129.69.text:
different perspective, where you learn something
new and are immersed in local communities,

134.79.text:
while at the same time, preserving and supporting
those communities.

139.96.text:
Where you or I, as a traveller, can spot thriving
wildlife that you’ve never seen before,

146.90.text:
surround yourself in some of the world’s
most stunning landscapes, be wowed, awe-struck,

153.04.text:
perhaps even inspired by what you see, while
at the same time, keeping it that way.

158.92.text:
Experiences where everyone involved gets something
positive out of it.

162.98.text: So, what did I get out of riding an elephant?

166.79.text:
I could tick it off my list. That’s about
it to be honest. I didn’t learn anything

171.91.text:
or feel like I understood elephants any better.
They just plonked me on top and off I went.

179.57.text:
Took a photo. Got off. NEXT!
What did the elephant get out of it?

183.53.text:
She was being controlled by the mahout with
a large hook, so she got a hook poked into

192.71.text:
her head repeatedly. Unlike horses and camels,
elephants spines are quite weak and not well

202.14.text:
equipped for carrying heavy goods or people.
She therefore also got a damaged spine from

208.04.text:
the large chairs they use which are far too
heavy and she got that for the entire day

211.88.text:
until she was chained up with no company or
entertainment.

217.52.text:
What did the local people get out of it? The
mahout for example.

222.05.text:
Well, the majority of mahouts live on site
at the elephant camps in appalling conditions.

228.60.text:
They are paid incredibly low salaries and
much of what they make is spent on keeping

233.55.text:
the elephant well enough to carry tourists
around all day. They are essentially trapped

238.62.text:
into a cycle of poverty. So, yeah, they don’t
get very much out of it either.

244.69.text:
And these are not the only issues that all
of us as well-meaning travellers trying to

248.41.text:
expand our horizons can unwittingly contribute
to.

251.68.text:
[Slide 5 – Orangutan]
Primates for example. How many of us would

255.99.text:
like to see the mountain gorillas or cuddle
a baby orangutan?

260.22.text:
Well, unfortunately, we’re genetically similar
to primates which means we only have to be

266.18.text:
within 15 metres of them to pass on a disease
and potentially wipe out an entire species.

273.01.text:
There have been documented cases of tourists
passing diseases to primates and very nearly

279.29.text:
doing just that. This happens, not because
we don’t care, but because we don’t know.

285.68.text:
Because we’re focusing on what we’re getting
out of it and forgetting about the animals.

290.53.text:
Animals, of course, are not the only ones
who fall victim to the negative impacts of

297.26.text:
tourism. The industry by its very nature often
involves people who are relatively wealthy

302.63.text:
(in a global sense) interreacting with people
who are relatively poor and this formula can,

309.18.text:
all too frequently lead to exploitation.
Many destinations have very lax laws and regulations

316.31.text:
around worker’s rights with higher paying
jobs and responsibilities given to foreigners

323.13.text:
rather than natives. Trekking porters are
a particularly vulnerable group.

329.01.text:
Required to carry heavy loads that we would
never dream of, they operate in some of the

335.39.text:
world’s harshest climates often with inadequate
clothing and equipment resulting in frostbite,

341.46.text:
permanent injury and even death. Again, this
happens, not when we don’t care, but when

348.81.text:
we forget about their needs and focus only
on what we, as travellers are getting out

353.87.text:
of it the experience.
Women and children too are often cruelly exploited

360.04.text:
not just by the infamous sex tourism industry
but also in orphanages. Many of us would be

368.80.text:
willing, perhaps even want to volunteer in
an orphanage, thinking that we are helping

375.14.text:
needy children, but sadly this is often not
the case.

378.40.text:
Nepal for example has over 800 orphanages,
that’s a lot of orphans. It may not come

387.20.text:
as a surprise that 80% of these are located
in the country’s tourist hotspots. What’s

392.49.text:
going on here? Sadly, the majority of these
orphanages are fake. What I mean is, these

399.81.text:
children are not orphans. They have been deceived
or even stolen from their parents to fuel

407.48.text:
the tourist demand for volunteering at an
orphanage.

412.19.text:
This has happened because we, as wealthier
westerners wanted to help, because we do care,

417.43.text:
but we focused too much on our needs and didn’t
stop to think about the bigger picture. We

422.87.text:
think nothing of volunteering at an orphanage
in Nepal for a week, but we wouldn’t be

428.82.text:
able to do that here in the UK. And for good
reason.

434.33.text:
A very visible way that irresponsible tourism
can damage local communities is when development

440.54.text:
goes ahead uncontrolled, hugely impacting
the environment. There are some parts of Danang

446.34.text:
in Vietnam that are now unrecognisable compared
to 10 years ago because you can barely see

453.04.text:
But a less visible impact is around water
equity. In many parts of the world, tourism’s

461.01.text:
demand for water has resulted in appropriation
of water supplies to the detriment of local

466.31.text:
domestic and agricultural needs. A good example
of this is in Bali, while the Indonesian island’s

474.17.text:
popular golf courses use 3 million litres
of water every day, villagers on some parts

479.27.text:
of the island reportedly have to walk up to
3km to collect water from a well. Perhaps

484.23.text:
we should have thought more about what the
local people were getting out of our visit

487.41.text:
These issues are not simple though. The relationship
is incredibly complex with many factors at

490.86.text:
play and many parties at fault. An example
of this is the so-called long-neck tribe in

496.52.text:
Thailand. Indigenous people and tribal communities
are especially vulnerable to exploitation

503.63.text:
and this tribe is at the heart of a complex
problem.

508.26.text:
You may have heard of this tribe, whose women
place rings around their necks in order to

512.57.text:
extend them by compressing the collar bone.
Whether you believe this traditional practice

516.50.text:
is ok or not is somewhat by the by, but what
we do know is that it was just beginning to

522.44.text:
die out until the tourists started showing
an interest.

526.51.text:
The volume of visitors to these remote villages
rose rapidly with tourist dollars becoming

532.91.text:
their primary source of income. The practice
of using the metal rings began to flourish

541.88.text:
once again despite having already lost much
of its cultural significance. A typical visit

547.64.text:
would involve a walk round the village, perhaps
looking at some local handicrafts and of course

551.90.text:
plenty of photos. It was all about looking.
Criticisms began to appear in the media, accusing

560.27.text:
these tours of being a “human zoo”. In
some ways they were right, there was no cultural

567.18.text:
exchange or interaction. So the tourists numbers
rapidly declined as travellers no longer wanted

574.89.text:
to be associated with the human zoo and the
tribe therefore lost their primary source

581.03.text:
of income.
As a minority group they have very few rights

586.37.text:
in Thailand, the majority are illiterate and
do not speak the local language and under

590.94.text:
current legislation they are not permitted
to leave the area of their village. They are

598.49.text:
now stuck. Stuck because we forgot to think
about what they would get out of it. We forgot

604.05.text:
to empower them, to ensure they were agents
in their own destiny and had a say in what

609.01.text:
was happening. Instead we focused on our desire
to see a remote and exotic tribe.

615.19.text:
So, now that I’ve thoroughly depressed you
all, I’m going to try and bring you back

621.34.text:
up. To reassure you that it doesn’t HAVE
to be this way. It is our belief at Rickshaw

626.83.text:
and my own personal belief that travelling
with meaning can be an incredible force for

634.51.text:
As I mentioned, tourism is unbelievably complex
and while getting too close to primates can

639.90.text:
spread disease, academics studying primates
believe that mountain gorillas would be extinct

645.37.text:
if not for tourism. Tourists pay through the
nose to see these incredible animals which

652.58.text:
is far more lucrative then the local bush
meat trade. This makes it in the local people’s

660.43.text:
interest to preserve them rather than hunt
them.

666.79.text:
I talked earlier about elephants. Should we
boycott all elephant experiences and interactions

673.40.text:
then? It’s just not that simple. A sudden
or total boycott would result in hundreds

681.29.text:
of animals being abandoned or even killed
– many simply cannot be rehabilitated back

687.19.text:
into the wild and without a lucrative income
their owners can no longer afford to keep

693.23.text:
them. A better alternative is to seek out
meaningful elephant experiences.

701.34.text:
At Rickshaw we offer an experience at the
Elephant Nature Park near Chiang Mai instead,

705.86.text:
a park that prides itself in its ethical treatment
of the elephants in its care, many of which

709.44.text:
have been rescued from the logging industry
and irresponsible tourist camps. Needless

710.67.text:
to say it operates a no riding policy. How
is it meaningful?

716.46.text:
What will you get out of it? The park provides
education to visitors and tourists alike about

722.31.text:
its elephants, helping you connect with each
one’s unique story. So unlike the elephant

728.16.text:
ride I did, you’ll learn something new,
and create a closer more meaningful connection

732.82.text:
with the animals because you’ll understand
them better.

736.03.text:
What do the elephants get out of it? The park
aids rehabilitation of the elephants wherever

742.03.text:
they can, and those that are permanent residents
are encouraged to live in a herd as they would

747.87.text:
in the wild. This way they can enjoy their
retirement, probably far more than I’ll

751.91.text:
be able to!
What about the local community? They can get

756.37.text:
employment at the park in positions which
pay a fair wage and empower them to make a

760.89.text:
difference. Even more than that though, the
park is Thai owned and run so the decisions

765.37.text:
made from a grassroots level and are sensitive
to Thai culture.

771.48.text:
I mentioned that irresponsible tourism can
destroy the natural environment, well meaningful

780.01.text:
At Rickshaw we offer a trip deep in the Sumatran
jungle in Indonesia. How is it meaningful?

788.35.text:
What do the local people get out of it? Well,
they were concerned by illegal logging in

793.69.text:
the area, which they could clearly see was
destroying the forest and it’s unique animals

798.43.text:
along with it. They grouped together to create
experiences here that travellers could enjoy

804.18.text:
and bring them into the area. Many of the
illegal loggers were local people trying to

809.61.text:
supplement their agricultural farms and were
exploited by the logging companies. They were

816.37.text:
approached and educated on what was happening
and soon realised they could make more money

822.21.text:
from retraining as guides than from illegal
logging. Many are now active conservationists

828.62.text:
and have a healthier income too. It’s been
a success for the local community because

833.62.text:
they’re involved in the decision-making
process.

837.30.text:
What does the environment get out of it? Once
the heart of illegal logging in Sumatra, this

843.46.text:
area now sees next to none. The jungle is
flourishing again and the critically endangered

849.19.text:
Sumatran orangutan has even been spotted in
the area.

853.18.text:
What will you get out of it? You’ll stay
in one of the world’s most remote jungles,

859.90.text:
surrounded by wildlife and lush vegetation
unlike anywhere else and you might even have

867.53.text:
a chance of spotting the Sumatran orangutan
yourself – from a safe distance of course!

873.71.text:
Meaningful travel can do even more for people
though. It can also build cultural bridges

878.82.text:
whilst bringing much needed funds to local
communities. We’ve all heard the cliché

883.45.text:
that Travel Broadens the mind, but you cannot
deny that direct interaction with different

888.69.text:
people from different walks of life builds
tolerance and understanding.

895.75.text:
At Rickshaw we have plenty of opportunities
to do this. One I tried myself is a stay on

904.19.text:
a small farm in rural Peru where I also helped
out with the daily tasks. How was this meaningful?

910.49.text:
What did my hosts get out of it? The funds
they received from my stay supplemented their

918.49.text:
existing income from the farm so they can
continue to preserve their cultural traditions

922.88.text:
rather than becoming dependent or reliant
on tourism. They had a sense of pride in their

928.80.text:
way of life as they could show it off to me,
and I’m pretty sure they got a few laughs

933.32.text:
out of my rather pathetic attempts to milk
a cow.

939.29.text:
What did I get out of it? Despite not speaking
a word of Spanish, and my hosts speaking very

944.04.text:
little English, I was able to interact directly
with them over breakfast. With the help of

948.36.text:
a trusty phrasebook and plenty of gesticulating
I was able to tell them about my life in the

955.22.text:
UK and they could tell me all about their
life on the farm. I learnt so much more and

961.47.text:
had a far better understanding than if I’d
just taken a walk round and looked at some

966.77.text:
handicrafts. And I learnt how to milk a cow
really badly!

969.79.text:
[Slide 15 – Cooking in Sri Lanka]
Through Rickshaw I also had the opportunity

975.11.text:
to cook a traditional Sri Lankan curry in
the home of a local woman who’s been whipping

979.09.text:
up curries for her family for years. How was
this meaningful?

982.42.text:
What did I get out of it? Well, just like
the Peruvian family I had a unique insight

987.88.text:
into her way of life that I wouldn’t have
been able to get from just having a look around.

990.14.text:
Being a huge curry fan I was also able to
add something truly authentic to my repertoire

996.63.text:
which has now become my go to dish when cooking
for friends and family. It always goes down

1002.05.text:
And what did she get out of it? Well, tourism
is unique in the sense that it gives women

1007.23.text:
as well as men opportunities to work and manage
their own finances. In this way she was empowered

1015.16.text:
and in control of the extra money being put
in her pocket. She was also very much in charge

1020.42.text:
of my performance in the kitchen giving our
relationship a more equal footing than if

1025.81.text:
I’d just been served a meal that she’d
made. And again, I’m pretty sure she had

1028.09.text:
a good laugh at my abysmal coconut grinding
skills!

1030.71.text:
I mentioned earlier that indigenous communities
are particularly vulnerable to exploitation

1035.88.text:
and cultural commodification, but at Rickshaw
we offer a trip to stay with the indigenous

1041.07.text: Kuna people in Panama. How is it meaningful?

1045.90.text:
What do the Kuna get out of it? Because the
Kuna own and run the lodges, because the guides

1052.49.text:
are from the community, they see most of the
income from travellers. They can maintain

1057.35.text:
their traditional way of life and feel a sense
of pride as they show it off to visitors on

1064.35.text:
What will you get out of it? Apart from meeting
and understanding a remote and unique community

1073.67.text:
who were using coconuts as currency until
the late 1990’s, you’ll be staying here.

1082.06.text:
I don’t know about you, but I’d definitely
rather be there right now!

1086.43.text:
What all these experiences have in common
is that everybody benefits. You or I as travellers

1093.25.text:
gain a unique insight into a completely different
way of life, learn new things, see amazing

1098.55.text:
animals and incredible landscapes.
And the local people have a say in that interaction,

1105.44.text:
they have some form of control over what happens
and are agents in their own destiny. The experience

1112.23.text:
is on an equal footing as it’s on their
terms as much as ours.

1118.99.text:
Ok, so how do you make sure you’re in the
camp that’s making people’s lives better?

1124.66.text:
How can you make sure your part of the solution
and not part of the problem? Tour operators

1132.85.text:
have a responsibility to do the right thing
where they can, so here are some things you

1137.25.text:
should check with them before you book:
1. Check whether they have a policy on sustainable

1143.27.text:
tourism or responsible travel or something
similar.

1150.62.text:
2. If they list any accreditation schemes,
follow up on them – check they still exist

1160.63.text:
and that this company is definitely listed.
3. Avoid companies who have lots of pictures

1169.95.text:
of tourists touching or feeding wildlife,
especially primates and check what education

1180.36.text:
is involved in their animal experiences.
4. If a trip helps to conserve the environment,

1191.79.text:
ask whether the local community are involved
in the decision making. Conservation only

1196.61.text:
really works when the local people benefit.
5. Go local – check whether the accommodation

1204.34.text:
is locally owned, are they using local guides?
This helps put money into local people’s

1215.75.text:
But there are also things which are ultimately
down to us as individuals – how we behave

1221.96.text:
when we get there.
1. Buy local. The money you spend in the destination

1229.50.text:
is free from tariffs so it’s a great way
to inject money directly where it’s needed

1233.61.text:
is by buying from local shops and eating at
local restaurants. It’s also a fantastic

1238.02.text:
way to immerse yourself in the local culture
and have a more enriching experience. I remember

1242.38.text:
being the only westerner in a local restaurant
in South India and being presented with a

1247.31.text:
masala dosa. I had no idea where to start
until a local family helped me out and showed

1255.96.text:
me how to eat it. It’s something I’ll
always remember and a really great unplanned

1259.50.text:
moment.
2. Get clued up. Familiarise yourself with

1265.40.text:
the local culture, customs and dress code.
You’re representing your home country while

1270.59.text:
you’re in theirs so it’s best to avoid
causing offence. You’ll also feel more like

1276.05.text:
you’re part of it – when you too take
your shoes off at the local Buddhist temple

1280.39.text:
you make a connection with the local people.
3. Watch your resource use. Remote destinations

1289.22.text:
in particular often suffer from a limited
supply of water or electricity. Do you really

1294.71.text:
need that towel washed?
4. Take your waste with you. There are so

1300.95.text:
many stunning locations around the world,
together we can keep them that way. You can

1306.68.text:
play your part by taking your litter away
with you, leaving plants and rocks where they

1308.98.text:
are and setting an example to locals and travellers
alike. We’d all hate to be that traveller

1314.63.text:
that accidently burnt down half a National
Park in Chile by being careless with their

1326.94.text:
By far the best way to travel is to really
throw yourself into the destination. Talk

1331.50.text:
to local people, explore, ask questions and
try new things. You may never develop a taste

1338.53.text:
for that Cambodian tarantula, but it’s sure
to make a great story!

1343.02.text:
I could waffle on forever about this topic
because it’s so close to my heart, but let

1351.50.text:
me just leave you with a few things to think
about.

1355.56.text:
It’s predicted that there will be 1.8 billion
international tourist arrivals by 2030 (doesn’t

1364.18.text:
include domestic tourism). That’s over a
5th of the global population travelling to

1370.47.text:
another country.
Tourism is the primary foreign exchange earner

1377.30.text:
for 65/69 less economically developed countries.
Imagine if all tourism was done right. If

1389.74.text:
all travellers behaved responsibly. What kind
of difference would that make to us as travellers

1396.97.text:
and to the local people, plants and animals.
Yes, it’s our holiday. Some of us have worked

1404.54.text:
long hours in stressful jobs so that we CAN
go on holiday. Of course we want to have a

1409.44.text:
good time while we’re there. But let’s
not forget that this is their home. How would

1415.32.text:
you normally behave in someone else’s home?
Let’s make sure that our once in a lifetime

1421.03.text:
adventure isn’t at their expense. Together
we CAN make a difference.

1427.02.text:
Thank you so much for listening. There are
a few handouts you can take if you’d like

1429.72.text:
to know more, which just leaves me to ask
any questions?
